section: Sources for Determining the Date of the Mahabharata War
text: Three historical sources determine the Mahabharata war's time. First, Magadha's history, available in our Puranas, often considered Bharat's history, lists Magadha's kings and dynasties in unbroken sequence from 36 years before Kali (3138 B.C.). These lists are in Vyasa's writings, an eyewitness to the war.  Second, Kashmir's history lists kings from about 300 years before the Mahabharata war, which it fixes at 36 years before Kali (3138 B.C.). Contemporary scholars' accounts of different kings and dynasties are strung together in this history. Twelve authors attempted continuous histories based on these accounts. Some incorporated traditional information and hearsay, leading to variations and conflicts. Kalhana, a later scholar, collated, compared them with inscriptions and other materials, removed doubtful parts, and created a cogent, consistent history of Kashmir. However, modern scholars attribute wilful changes, exaggerations, and additions to Kalhana, editing the lists beyond recognition.  Third, Nepal's history begins 1000 years before the Mahabharata war, listing kings and reigns with dates on the Kali Era. Modern historians have tampered with, edited, and misinterpreted all three sources to fit their prejudices and corroborate their theories of a reduced antiquity for the Mahabharata war. Books by these scholars and their disciples are studied in our schools and colleges, depriving our youth of Bharat's true history. The basis of a true and correct history of Bharat is the time of the Mahabharata war. This volume attempts to fix the war at 36 years before Kali (3138 B.C.) and establish this determination beyond doubt based on evidence from epics, Puranas, indigenous records, astronomical treatises, and inscriptions.

The events that led to the War
A Great Prince named Santana, belonging to the Lunar race of Kshatriyas was ruling at Hastinapura during the period of transition from the Dwapara to the Kali Yuga about 300 years before Kali i.e., 3401 B.C. He had two sons, Bhishma by his first wife 'Ganga' and Vichitra Virya, by his second wife Satyavadhi. The devoted son Bhishma, renounced his right to the succession to the throne, desisted from marriage and remained a life-long bachelor, to please his father. His step-brother Vichitra Virya, who therefore succeeded Santana to the throne, in his turn begot two sons. The elder of the two, Dhritarashtra was born blind, therefore disqualified to succeed to the throne according to law. So the right to the throne devolved on his younger brother Pandu. But out of his regard and consideration for his elder brother, Pandu placed him on the throne nominally and carried on the administration on his behalf. A princess named Gandhari (daughter of the King of Gandhara), chose to marry the blind King Dhritarashtra. She was such a devoted and exemplary wife that she lived blind-folded to the end of her life to avoid for herself the privilege of sight denied to her husband. She had a hundred sons by Dhritarashtra. They are the well-known one hundred Kauravas of the Mahabharata. The prince Pandu begot five sons; Yudhishtira and his illustrious brothers, the Pandavas. While the Pandavas were still in their boyhood, Pandu retired to the forest for austerities and passed away there. Bhishma sent for the Pandavas and arranged for the coronation of the five Pandavas along with the hundred Kauravas at Hastinapura. The malicious Kauravas tried a number of ways to bring the Pandavas to harm but failed in all their attempts. At last on the advice of Veda Vyasa, Dhritarashtra divided his kingdom into two parts, handed over one half to the Pandavas, and kept the other half for himself, to be administered by his eldest son, Duryodhana whom he nominated the crown prince. Yudhishtira, the eldest of the Pandava princes ruled over the half of the kingdom that fell to his share with Indra-Prastha (or Sakra-Prastha) as his capital. His reign at Indra-Prastha commenced in the 75th year before Kali (i.e., B.C. 3177). In that year the Saptarshi Mandala the constellation of the Great Bear crossed over into the region of the Star Magha. It remains in the Magha for 26 hundred years from 3177 B.C. before crossing over into the region of the next star on the Zodiac. Up till now Hastinapura was the capital of a kingdom. The land of the Kurus was just one of the many separate kingdoms of Bharat. But the Pandavas conquered with the might of their arms a number of other kingdoms, added considerably to their inherited territory and ruled over a vast empire extending over the entire Bharat and even beyond the river Sindhu on the west and the Himalayas on the north, including the frontier Kingdoms of Yona, Huna, Romaka, Bahlika (Bactria), Darada, Turushkasihan (Turkistan), Sakasthan (East Persia) and other territories occupied by the Mlechcha (ex-communicated Hindu Kshatriyas) princes and included in the frontiers of ancient Bharat. The eldest Pandava prince, Yudhishtira thus became the Emperor of the entire Bharat, performing the Rajasuya Sacrifice, the traditional test of suzerainty.

Duryodhana, their cousin of Hastinapura was filled with envy at the glory earned by the Pandavas, invited Yudhishtira to a game of dice, and with the help of his uncle Sakuni, who was an adept at the game, defeated him. According to the rules of the game, the specified stakes for which the game was played, were obliged to spend a period of 12 years, along with their wife, the illustrious Draupadi, in the forest and another year after that, somewhere in disguise without being detected and if they happened to be detected before the year was completed, again a period of 12 years in the forest and so on, their empire to be returned to them when the term of exile was successfully completed. Thus for a time Duryodhana became the emperor by virtue of his success in the game of dice, to which he managed to entice Yudhishtira, and no act of valour or conquest on his part. But when the Pandavas fulfilled the conditions laid down, completed the term of 12 years of exile in the forest, 1 year of exile incognito, and claimed their empire, he refused to return it to them. This was the reason for the Great war.
On account of the consideration that Bhishma had been an honoured prince at the Kaurava court from the beginning, ever since the times of Santana and Pandu, he participated in the war on the side of the Kauravas. He was 236 years old at the time of the war and he was elder to Veda Vyasa by about 20 years. Yudhishtira was 91, Bhima 90, Arjuna 89, and the twins Nakula and Sahadeva 88. Sri Krishna was of the same age as Bhima, i.e., 90 years. The Kauravas and all their supporters were destroyed in the Great war. All the five Pandavas won the victory and survived. 36 years after the Bharata War, the entire Yadava race, to which Sri Krishna belonged, fell a prey to internecine quarrels and perished fighting with one another at the Prabhasa Tirtha. Sri Krishna survived the Mahabharata war for 36 years, i.e., lived up to the age of 90 + 36 = 126 years and in his 126th year shuffled off his carnal body. It is so recorded in the Mahabharata by Sri Veda Vyasa. The battle at Kurukshetra was confined to 18 days only. On the 19th all the ladies of the royal family of the Kauravas proceeded to the battlefield along with Kunti, the mother of the Pandavas, and Gandhari, the mother of Kauravas, for a last sight of the corpses of their husbands, sons and other relations.

Somadhi ruled Magadha for 58 years, both during Dwapara alongside Yudhishtira and in Kaliyuga as a contemporary of Parikshit. This account aligns with Pargiter's 'Dynasties of the Kali Age'. Therefore, the Mahabharata War is believed to have occurred in 3138 BC at the end of Dwapara, 36 years before the beginning of Kaliyuga.  The beginning of Kaliyuga is linked to the demise of Sri Krishna in 3102 BC, a date largely undisputed even by Western scholars. Consequently, the Mahabharata war, in which Krishna played a pivotal role, must have taken place 36 years prior, in 3138 BC.  However, some scholars, motivated by a desire to minimize the antiquity of Indian history, dispute this timeline. They have promoted an alternative theory based on an interpolation in the Rajatarangini, suggesting a later date for the war. This has misled Indian historians. If the accepted start of Kaliyuga is considered, the Mahabharata war's date of 3138 BC becomes evident.

To reconstruct ancient Indian history and determine the timelines of significant figures, establishing the start of the Yudhishtira Saka is crucial. This era began with Yudhishtira's coronation as emperor after the 18-day Mahabharata war.  The Yudhishtira Saka is practically synonymous with the time of the Mahabharata War, differing only by 28 days.  Therefore, fixing the Yudhishtira Saka necessitates first firmly establishing the date of the war.  Among discovered Indian inscriptions, most belong to the Christian era, with few predating it. This raises concerns about potential suppression or destruction of inscriptions from the Mahabharata period to obscure India's ancient history.  It's improbable that no inscriptions exist from the era before the Mahabharata war, given the widespread practice of recording achievements and gifts, as evidenced by later inscriptions. This suggests deliberate destruction. One example is the Kumbhalagarh inscription (1517 VS), found in broken pieces, indicating intentional damage and dispersal. It likely contained information contradicting established narratives.

Dr. G.N. Sarma discusses the fragmented Kumbhalagarh inscription (1517 VS/1460 AD) found in the Victoria Hall Museum, Udaipur. He reconstructed the text using the 'Prasasti Sangraha' manuscript. The inscription details Bappa, a Brahmin from Anandapur, who served Harita and was granted rulership. This affirms Bappa's Brahmin origin, a fact supported by various inscriptions and historical texts. This contradicts theories portraying Rajput rulers as descendants of foreign invaders or low-caste natives. The deliberate destruction of this inscription suggests an attempt to suppress the true origin of the Rajputs and uphold fabricated narratives.  The inscription highlights the tradition of Brahmins adopting Kshatriya roles, a concept evident in the term 'Brahma Kshatri'.  Such destruction of evidence indicates a systematic effort to manipulate historical narratives.
Shortly after the Mahabharata War and Yudhishtira's coronation, Parikshit was born. Thirty-six years later, Sri Krishna passed away on February 20th, 3102 BC.

section: Topic IV: Conjunction of Seven Planets and Panchangas (Annual Calendars)
text:
Yudhishtira became the Emperor of Bharat after his victory in the Mahabharata War. In the 36th year of his rule as Emperor, his cousin Sri Krishna, who had been his strong support and played a prominent part in the conduct of the war, passed away in Dwarska. The Puranas and the Mahabharata are all unanimous in declaring that the commencement of the Kali Yuga is reckoned from the moment of the demise of Sri Krishna (i.e., 3102 B.C.). The Vishnupurana in sloka 12-2-33 says...

Kali Era is not a matter of guesswork but is based on the solid foundations of Astronomical Science. According to our Astronomical science, the seven planets (1. Saturn; 2. Jupiter; 3. Mars, 4. Sun, 5. Venus, 6. Mercury, and 7. Moon) should be in conjunction (together) in the Mesha at the commencement of the Kali Era. 5060 years back, such a phenomenon occurred in 3102 B.C., at 2 hours 27 minutes and 30 seconds on 20th February. The Kali Era is reckoned from that moment. (This type of conjunction of the planets will recur again at the next such moment in the next Mahayuga after 43,20,000 years). The well-known French Astronomer Bailly and others admitted that the conjunction of the planets described by our Hindu Astronomers occurred exactly correctly to the minute and second at the time noted by them.

Prof. Count Bjornsljerna says: “According to the Astronomical calculations of the Hindus, the present period of the world, Kaliyuga commenced 3102 years before the birth of Christ, on the 20th February, at 2 hours 27 minutes and 30 seconds, the time being thus calculated to minutes and seconds. They say that a conjunction of the planets then took place, and their tables show this conjunction. Bailly states that Jupiter and Mercury were there in the same degree of the ecliptic, Mars at a distance of only eight, and Saturn of seven degrees; whence it follows, that at the point of time given by the Brahmins as the commencement of Kaliyuga, the four planets above mentioned must have been successively concealed by the rays of the sun (First Saturn, then Mars, afterwards Jupiter, and lastly Mercury). They thus showed themselves in conjunction; and although Venus could not then be seen, it was natural to say that a conjunction of the planets then took place. The calculations of the Brahmins is so exactly confirmed by our own Astronomical tables, that nothing but an actual observation could have given so correspondent a result.” (Vide Hindu Superiority 2.2. 252-484 by Har Bilas Sarda, third edition, 1922.)

PANCHANGAS (ANNUAL CALENDARS)
All the Panchangas (Native Annual Calendars) in vogue in the different parts of Bharat, in which the positions and movements of the different planets and stars on the Zodiac during the year are recorded and their influence on the lives of human beings are predicted, have all been prepared year after year from times immemorial, and from the entrance of Kali, reckoning the time on the Kali Era and adding up year after year. The Kali Era is the basis of all reckoning of time in these calendars. In the calendars for the current year 'Vikari' of A.D. 1959, it will be found stated that 5060 years have gone since the Kaliyuga commenced. The Mahabharata War is to be dated 36 years previous to the advent of Kali, i.e., 5060 years back, i.e., 5060 + 1958 A.D. = 3138 B.C. This is the direct determination of the date of the Mahabharata War on the basis of our Native Annual Calendars, which form a National Institution in our country.

In a native historical treatise, the 'Kali Yuga Raja Vrittanta' (history of the kings of the Kali Yuga), it is stated:

“When Yudhishtira was crowned King at Indraprastha, over his half of the Kaurava kingdom carved out for the Pandavas, the Constellation of the Great Bear or the Saptarshi Mandala entered the region of the star Magha, in the Zodiac.”

And again:

“Seventy-five years before the commencement of the Kali Yuga, the Great Bear crossed over into Magha, i.e., in B.C. (3102 - 75 =) 3177. Yudhishtira's reign at Indraprastha therefore commenced in B.C. 3177.”

The 75 years of his reign before Kali include 25 years of Suzerainty (Emperorship) over the whole of Bharat, which he enjoyed after the performance of the Rajasuya, the 13 years of exile as a consequence of his defeat in the game of Dice, 38 years on the whole, and the demand for the restoration of his kingdom as per the terms of the game at the end of the 13 years of exile, the refusal of Duryodhana to comply with the demand, and the War in 3138 B.C., the coronation of Yudhishtira again after the War as the undisputed Emperor of Bharat and the establishment of the Yudhishtira Era, 35 years of his rule after the War and the demise of Sri Krishna, the advent of Kali, his renunciation of the kingdom, entrusting it to Parikshit and starting on the Great Journey, in 3101 B.C.

And thereafter it is stated:

“After the passage of 25 years in the Kali Yuga, i.e., in B.C. (3102 - 25) 3077, the Great Bear, in its retrograde motion, passes on from Magha to Aslesha and remains in it for a hundred years.”

And:

“Then, i.e., in B.C. 3077, Yudhishtira, after completing the Great Journey or Pilgrimage around the world, ascends to heaven.”

“Even then, i.e., in B.C. (3077 - 76 + 9) =, an Era was inaugurated in memory of Yudhishtira, the Secular Era variously called Laukikabda, Saptarshimana, Yudhishtira Swargarohana Kala, the Kashmir-abda, of a duration of 3700 years.”

From the account thus available to us in the Kaliyuga Raja Vrittanta, the dates of four well-known events are authoritatively fixed for us:

1. The entry of the Great Bear into Magha: 3177 B.C.
2. The time of the Mahabharata War or Yudhishtira Era: 3138 B.C.
3. The commencement of the Kali Yuga: 3102 B.C.
4. The inauguration of the Saptarshi Era, or Yudhishtira Swargarohana Kala, or Laukikabda or Kashmir-abda: 3076 B.C.

The fourth of these, called 'Laukikabda' because it was established by the people, Yudhishtira Kala, as it was established in memory of Yudhishtira, as 'Swargarohana Kala', and Kashmir-abda as it has been in vogue in Kashmir all along and used by the almanac makers as the basis of their calculations from year to year. Kalhana, the author of the history of Kashmir, known as Raja Tarangini, has used this Laukikabda as the basis of his chronology.

Dr. Buhler, the well-known European Historian, himself has admitted the antiquity of this Laukikabda, the validity of the recognition of its starting point, Kali 1, as equivalent to B.C. 3101.

“I do not doubt for a moment that the calculation which throws the beginning of the Saptarshi Era back to 3076 B.C. is worth no more than that which fixes the beginning of the Kali Yuga in 3101 B.C. But it seems to me certain that it is much older than Kalhana’s time, because his equation 24 = 1070 agrees with it. It may therefore be safely used for reducing with exactness the Saptarshi years, months, and days mentioned in his work to years of the Christian Era. The results which will be thus obtained will always closely agree with those gained by Gen. Cunningham, who did use the right key.” (Vide pp. 264-268, Indian Antiquary Vol. VI of 1877 and p. 27 ff. of Vol. V of the Edn. 1876.)

Besides, Dr. Buhler himself quotes the following verse in evidence of the currency of the Saptarshi Era in Kashmir:

“After 25 years passed away in Kali, Yudhishtira and his brothers ascended to heaven.”

Dr. Buhler has interpolated in the above verse 'Saptarshivaryah' in place of 'Yudhishtiradyah'. But the emendation leads to no sensible meaning for the verse. For, the Saptarshis are always in heaven. There is no sense in stating that they will be in heaven in Kali 25. It is certainly sensible and meaningful to state, according to the other reading, that Yudhishtira and his brothers, who had been on the earth since 75 years before Kali, ascended to heaven, or passed away from the earth, in Kali 25. This is the version in the Puranas too. section: Saptarshi Era and Age of Mahabharata War
text:
In Kashmir's almanacs, the "Saptarshi-mana" is used for time determinations. Dr. Buhler admitted Kali 1 as B.C. 3101 and Saptarshi Kali 26 as B.C. 3076. He acknowledged the Great Bear (Saptarshi Mandala) entering Magha in B.C. 3177 and the era starting after their entry into Aslesha in B.C. 3076. This shows he knew of the Saptarshi's 100-year stay in Magha (B.C. 3177-3077), the Puranic descriptions of Yudhishtira's reign spanning a century, and verses in 'Brihatsamhita' and 'Rajatarangini'. He therefore knew the Mahabharata War occurred in B.C. 3138, but this truth was withheld.

Astronomer Varahamihira, in 'Brihatsamhita' XIII-3 (also 'Rajatarangini' I-56), refers to Yudhishtira's reign, his ascent to heaven, and the Saka Era. This verse connects Yudhishtira's ascent (basis of chronological reckoning), the Saka Era, Yudhishtira's reign, and the Great Bear's movement. This era is also called Laukikabda, Yudhistirakala, Saptarshimana, and Kashmirabda.

The verse states: "The Saptarshis were in Magha during Yudhishtira's reign. Yudhishtira's ascent plus 2526 years is Saka-Kala." The Saptarshi Mandala moved from Magha to the next star in Kali 26, marking the start of the Saptarshimana/Yudhistirakala/Laukikabda/Kashmirabda era. The Saka Era in Varahamihira's time began in Kali 26 + 2526 = Kali 2552 or B.C. 550.  Varaha, to fix the Saka Era's start, linked the Saptarshi Mandala in Magha with Yudhishtira's reign. He then stated the Saka Era began 2526 years after Yudhishtira's ascent (Kali 26).

There's no reference to the Salivahana Saka.  If Varaha meant Salivahana Saka (Kali 3179), it would be 3153 years from Yudhishtira's ascent (Kali 26), not 2526.  Therefore, another Saka Era existed. We must consider the Saka Kala of Kali 2552, not the Salivahana Saka of Kali 3179. Varaha fixed Yudhishtira's reign to when the Saptarshis were in Magha.  Bhattotpala, commenting on 'Brihatsamhita' XIII-3, quoted Vriddhagarga: "Kalidwapara Sandhautu Sthitasthe Pitrudaivalam" (Pitrudaivalam was at Kalidwapara Sandhi).  "Kalidwapara Sandhi" is when Dwapara Yuga ended and Kali Yuga began (36 years after the Mahabharata War, on February 20th, B.C. 3102).  The Great Bear was then in Magha.

Dr. Cunningham's table in 'Indian Eras' shows the Saptarshi Mandala's location from B.C. 5877 to A.D. 2125, placing it in Magha from B.C. 3177 to 3077. This agrees with Vriddha Garga, Varahamihira, Bhattotpala, and other ancient Indian scholars. Thus, the Saptarshi Mandala entered Magha 75 years before Kali Yuga (B.C. 3102), i.e., in B.C. 3177.  Yudhishtira was crowned in B.C. 3177, expanded his empire, performed Rajasuya, became Emperor, lost his kingdom in B.C. 3151, was exiled for 13 years (until B.C. 3138), fought the Mahabharata War, regained his empire, and in B.C. 3102, after Krishna's Nirvana and Kali Yuga's start, renounced his empire, went on pilgrimage, and ascended to heaven in B.C. 3077.

Varahamihira's verse states Yudhishtira ruled from B.C. 3177-3077 while the Saptarshis were in Magha.  Adding 2526 to Yudhishtira's Swargarohana Kala (B.C. 3076) gives the Saka-Kala of Varaha's time: Kali 26 + 2526 = Kali 2552 or B.C. 550.  This is based solely on Varahamihira's statements. Thus, we establish the Saptarshi's Magha century (B.C. 3177-3077), the start of Yudhishtira Kala (B.C. 3076), and Varaha's Saka Era (B.C. 550).  Conjecturing Varaha meant the Salivahana Saka and twisting the verse's meaning is unwarranted.

section: Age of the Mahabharata War - Wrong Conjectures
text: At the time of the Mahabharata War, correctly determined, the Pandavas, Draupadi, Sri Krishna, the Kauravas, Bhishma, Drona and other Bharata Warriors must be in existence. It should be the transition time from Dwapara to Kali. The Constellation of the seven sages be in the star region of Magha. It has been admitted on all hands by the Astronomical Scholars of ancient Bharat, the European Orientalists like Dr. Buhler and General Alexander Cunningham that the Constellation of the seven sages was in the Magha region from B.C. 3177 to B.C. 3077. The Astronomers, the authors of the Puranas of ancient Bharat, all unanimously declare that Yudhishtira was reigning during that century. That the ascent of Yudhishtira to heaven occurred in B.C. 3076 or Kali 26 when the Constellation passed over from Magha to the next stars is conceded by Dr. Buhler, Dr. Wilson and General Alexander Cunningham. How could Sri Krishna who passed away in B.C. 3102 and the Pandavas who passed away in B.C. 3077-76 be alive in B.C. 2448 or 1931, 1886, 1500, 1400, 1100, or 900 if any of the conjectures be correct, of the modern historians of Ancient Bharat, the European Orientalists or their Indian disciples? How could the Constellation of the seven sages which was in Magha in B.C. 3177 to B.C. 3077-76, be in any of the years noted above? Is there any inscriptional or historical authority for their determination? Such determinations and arguments deserve only the contempt of genuine historians and competent scholars. The final result of all the above discussion is the time of the Mahabharata War is indisputably B.C. 3138, when the Saptarshimandala was in Magha century.

section: Age of the Mahabharata War - Inscriptional Evidence
text: There are four inscriptions, extant and available to us (apart from several others that might have been lost or destroyed), which prove conclusively that the Mahabharata War occurred in B.C. 3138 or 36 years before Kali. Of these four, two have been published in the Indian Antiquary. The third does not seem to have attracted the attention of the Government Archaeological Department. It has been copied from the person in possession of it and published recently at Masulipatam in the Krishna District. The fourth is the copper plate inscription of Emperor Sudhanvan. The contents of these four inscriptions bear out the determination, without scope for any doubt, that the Mahabharata War occurred in B.C. 3138. It is hoped that this evidence at least will be respected by the Modern Indian historians and they will be able to reconstruct the correct history of ancient Bharat on the basis of it. Sri Krishna passed away in B.C. 3102, the Kali Yuga commenced simultaneously. In Kali 1 or B.C. 3101 Yudhishtira renounced his Empire, installed Parikshit on the imperial throne and started with his brothers on the Mahaprasthana or the Great Journey. Parikshit reigned for 60 years and died due to snake-bite in B.C. 3041. His son Janamejaya was crowned in B.C. 3041. In the 29th year of his reign i.e., in B.C. 3013-3012 or Kali 89, in the year Plavanga on Monday the new moon day at the beginning of Chaitra, he donated two villages to two religious institutions and the two gift-deeds were inscribed. One of these is found published in the pages 333, 334 of the Indian Antiquary.

text: The Kali Yuga began in 3102 B.C., while the Mahabharata War took place in 3138 B.C., the same year Parikshit was born and the Yudhishthira Era began. The Saptarshi Mandala (constellation of the Seven Sages) enters each star region for 100 years.  Puranic authors and astronomers used the position of the Saptarshi Mandala relative to the reigns of kings to maintain chronological accuracy, preventing discrepancies. Initially unaware of this system, European Orientalists later recognized its value in exposing their own erroneous chronological determinations, which aimed to downplay the antiquity of Indian history.  This natural and verifiable method of timekeeping, based on the movement of the Saptarshi Mandala, could not be dismissed.

section: Calculating Time from Parikshit to the Andhras
text: From Parikshit's birth to Mahapadma Nanda's coronation, 1500 years elapsed. From Mahapadma Nanda to the Andhras (Poulomas), another 836 years passed, totaling 2336 years according to Puranic scholars.  At Parikshit's birth, the Seven Sages were in Krittika. After a 2700-year cycle through 27 stars, they returned to Krittika during the Andhra period. By the time of the 24th Andhra king, Siva Satakarni, in 2705 Yudhishthira Saka, they were back in Krittika. The subsequent eight Andhra kings ruled for another 106 years, bringing the total time from the Mahabharata War (3138 B.C.) to the end of the Andhra dynasty to 2811 years. Thus, the Andhra dynasty ended in 327 B.C., coinciding with the start of the Gupta dynasty.  This places Alexander's invasion of India (326 B.C.) contemporary with Chandragupta of the Gupta dynasty, not Chandragupta Maurya.

section: Sir William Jones and Prof. Max Muller's Theories on Indian History
text: Sir William Jones initially proposed a limited chronology for Indian history, suggesting that the historical age couldn't be traced back further than 2000 BC. He later revised his view, acknowledging the Barhadra dynasty of Magadha and identifying Chandragupta Maurya, not the Gupta king, as the contemporary of Alexander the Great. This adjustment reduced the timeline of Magadha's history by 1200 years. Prof. Max Muller, initially a proponent of the Central Asian origin of Aryans, later embraced the idea that they were native to the Ganges region, the birthplace of the human race. He emphasized the antiquity and preservation of Sanskrit, its relationship to European languages, and the importance of Indian history for a comprehensive education. He expressed great respect for Indian culture and wisdom, yet under pressure from Orientalists, declared Chandragupta Maurya as Alexander's contemporary in 1859, thus establishing a false historical foundation. He acknowledged the pressure and motivations behind his declaration, perhaps hoping Indian historians would eventually rectify the error.

section: Mr. M. Troyer's Objection and Max Muller's Response
text: Mr. M. Troyer, translator of Kalhana's Rajatarangini, objected to Max Muller's declaration, asserting that Chandragupta of the Gupta dynasty, not the Maurya, was Alexander's contemporary. Other European Orientalists also pointed out this error. Despite this, Max Muller maintained his stance, unable to provide supporting evidence but citing the perceived strength of the evidence for the Maurya identification. This false theory, backed by Muller's authority, has significantly impacted the understanding of ancient Indian history, leading to doubts about historical events due to its contradiction with indigenous literature. The discrepancy between the established date of Maurya Chandragupta (1534 BC) and Gupta Chandragupta (327 BC) is approximately 1200 years, pushing the Mahabharata War's date forward significantly. Max Muller ultimately expressed regret over the potential injustice done to Indian history due to questionable sources and lack of thorough investigation.
